q.a: so basically if you just played this as 32nd notes, no one would ever know the difference. we're talking about squeezing 16 notes into 2 beats at 80bpm. grouping it evenly in thirds as 5+5+6 is not really going to be distinguishible from even 16, from the listener's or player's perspective. i would ask the composer what the point was of writing it that way, and maybe they could give you some insight as to how it's played. sometimes composers like to showoff on the page how many crazy looking numbers they can put in, now i'm not suggesting that this composer would do such a thing! but it's worth a thought
q.q: Hey, I asked the question about that 5,5,6 triplet thing! So, the song is in 4/4 time (slower tempo, about 80bpm). The full measure is a dotted eighth, then a sixteenth note tied to a quarter note, then that 5,5,6, triplet thing. So that 5,5,6 triplet should take up 2 beats. So, it's like dividing 2 beats into 3 equal parts (3:2 quarter note triplet), then taking those 3 equal parts and dividing them again into 5,5, and 6 respectively?

q.a: tuplets actually have a hidden number. any time you see the "3" for triplet, it's actually shorthand for "3:2" which means '3 notes in the time there would normally be 2 of these.' when 5's and 6's are used, it can be ambiguous whether it means 5:2 or 5:4, but regardless it is easy to figure out by looking at the context. but the time under the triplet bracket should be divided in 3, and then each of those thirds divided into 5, 5, and 6. or, for a reasonable human, just play 16 (oh wow, just realized the strange implications of this) notes in that time .... So really all this is saying is, play it like 32nd notes (or 16ths, depending on whether the triplet bracket takes up a whole bar or half a bar, that you can discern by looking at what else is in the bar)... so yeah basically the only technical difference between this and 32nd notes is basically they are just asking you to play the first 10 notes slower by an extremely negligible and unnoticeable amount. unless of course the rest of the music is in triplets anyway, in which case it would be normal to divide it in 3's. a lot of questions here that the context will answer. such as the tempo, and what the notes are

Ive never seen a tuplet inside of a tuplet before... How am I supposed to play that?

q.a: i'm hearing different ones than you are mentioning, like the one that comes out most prominently is the top of bar 2 (in 6/8) there is a loud F note (out of key). this is a hammer-on, from the wrong half of the string. this only happens acoustically, and it happens worse when you are playing in the middle of the string (or in the high fret range). if you do a hammer-on, it vibrates the correct half of the string (which gives you the note you want) but also the back half of the string (to the left of your left hand). on electric, you usually wouldn't hear it. but unplugged, the 2 notes will be of equal volume if the note is near the middle of the string. so in this case it is exactly in the middle of the string (12th fret) so both sides resonate equally. on a fretless instrument i think this would be the same note, but because it's fretted instrument, the target point to press is actually on the right bar of the fret, not the left. but the reverse note is happening from the other side, from the bar on the left side of the fret. so it's a slightly shorter distance. so you'll get F instead of E. this is not the note that you mentioned, but it seems to be the loudest and most obvious one right from the very beginning. the reason it is particularly problematic is because he's hitting it harder, for groove's sake, since it's the downbeat of the bar. really to avoid this in an acoustic close-mic situation is you have to try not to hammer as hard with the left hand, and do more of the work with your right hand. the rest of the quiet out-of-tune notes i believe are also unwanted reverse hammer-ons, but as we get closer to the left (the head? neck? sorry don't really know guitar terms, i am not a guitar player) the reverse hammer-on would be quieter, and higher. wherever you do a hammer-on, the lower (longer) of the 2 notes will be louder. that's just my analysis. i'm not really a guitar player

q.a: without hearing what you're doing, i can make some guesses. make sure something is doing the 'bass' -- that means, make sure there is something playing single notes in a low range (between 1 and 3 octaves below middle C). just try some things, you will soon learn what you want to do. but you need to be using that range, at least for some of the song (hopefully for like the 'main' parts of the song. or perhaps the whole time). also another thing i can suggest, don't be goal oriented in piling on instruments. and the main thing i would suggest is, make sure you know what the song is about before adding any instruments, or at the very latest you need to know what the song is about by the time you have added the second instrument. also there is a 90% chance your song should either have words associated with it in some prominent way, or if not it needs to be strongly associated with a video or story line. instruments are just nebulous sounds -- very powerful, but nebulous -- if you want to really get things done here, you will need something that makes sense to the front part of your brain. (words, concepts, characters, things you can identify like a cat or a dog, etc. that sort of thing) ... if you have that, then the instruments and sounds can work to their full effect, seemingly enhancing the power of those items in front. just some general hints from the way i usually look at things, although there are surely other ways to do it
q.q: Now I'm trying to add new instruments and sections to my song. I pick an instrument and write a harmony for it, record it, listen to it, and it sounds bad. I do this like 5-20 times before getting something that works with what I already have, and all this trying things and not having them work out makes me sad. Ergo, working on music tends to leave me sad instead of satisfied. What should I do?

Am I just wasting my time in school? I know that you at least went to high school (and partially to college, I think, I dunno), but you knew that (1) you learn better when you taught yourself and (2) you had nothing to gain from school. Now, though, I'm kind of yearning for a challenge: as you said, I wanna be somet hing, go somewhere, do something. I want things to change. None of this seems to be happening for my in school. q.q: Hey, so I think you say that you usually write the melody and harmony of a song together... Just wondering where rhythm fits into this?

q.a: drums and bass are not necessarily part of the writing. sometimes there will be hints at what's supposed to happen, but writing the song usually does not include deciding exactly what everyone is going to play. when it comes time to do the song, then the players (which all happen to be me) use their best judgement for how to do the song. it's like making a movie or tv show. the script mainly has dialogue, and some basic info about scenes and sets. but the writers don't build the sets, and they are not making decisions about every little item that goes everywhere on the set. that is done by the set designers, but they are doing it based on the way the script seems to imply it should be, even though the details may not be written in the script. they are using their judgement based on the what they can infer from the script
q.q: I guess a melody has its own implied rhythm. But do you usually write/record drums and bass last?

q.a: the vast majority of songwriting for me is based on the melody/lyric, but a small number of times i have found a certain groove or chord sequence that i think is basis for a song, so it is entered into the song list. i don't recall if any of those have ever made it to the next step

i tried to find everything i've ever written; stories, fictions, novel ideas, lyrics, text roleplays, one-shots, prompts, poems and even the stupid weird, you know, "things" from primary school. i gathered all of them and checked them over to see if they are useful, to take the good ones and finish projects.
after all this time i didn't write anything but a scenario for a school play, probably because it destroyed my whole life and i gave everything i had to it (i thought it would be a simple and small play since we do it for school but since i always want to do everything perfect, i somehow kinda became the director and wrote 13000 fucking words, with history researching, songs, stage decor, costumes, lighting etc it took 7 damn months of my life and i even fucking translated a nurse's journal and a soldier's war letters in Ottoman Turkish which was simply Arabic, a language that i don't know, for play to be realistic), i hoped reading m y old wo rks would make me do something.

q.a: in this school of thinking, 7th chords descending chromatically is a legit and normal thing, just like 7th chords moving down a fifth / up a fourth is considered legit. in either case, the internal tritone harmony (B and F notes in a G7 chord) can be seen as moving down chromatically regardless.
q.q: But I thought moving a chord either a half step up or a half step down to the 'target chord' was a trick that works no matter what chord your playing?

q.a: i think tritone substitution refers to any time you have a 7th chord with the tritone harmony in it (like a G7 chord contains the notes B and F) and then you switch the bass note for a Db note, which essentially makes a Db7 chord instead, because the core notes (B, F) are the same. Additionally, any other notes you were using in the chord can usually translate to the other, and usually a light-dark or dark-light transformation occurs. for example if you had G7 with 9, 13, (the 'light' notes) and you flip the bass to Db, and leave all the same notes, they become the 'dark' notes on the Db7 so it becomes Dbaug7#9. This whole line of thinking is generally only applicable in the school of thinking that the notes B and F with G in the bass should resolve to C and E, with C in the bass. or B and F with Db in the bass resolve to F# and A# with F# in the bass. so why not switch
q.q: Like if you playing a blues song in C and for the little V-IV-I turnaround you hit a G#7 before going to the G7... would that be a tritone substitution too (the 5th of G is D, tritone of D is G#)?

q.q: Regarding the french augmented sixth chord: The chord is used in cadences. In the key of c, the French augmented sixth chord would be Ab-C-D-F# leading to the 'clean V' (as I call it), G-B-D-G, or even better, the Gsus4. The most common use of the augmented sixth chord (google it if you're into nerdy music theory) is the German augmented sixth chord; Ab-C-Eb-F# (in the key of c), that then leads to the cadential dominant 6/4 chord (G-C-E-G) that leads to the 'clean V' and finally to the tonic of c. As a professional classical musician, the German aug. sixth chord is by far my favorite chord (in cadences), so I guess my question is; now that you know about it and you're good at writing catchy jingles, would you consider using it in your music?

(i'm not asking about theory btw hahahaha, please don't move to space, we like having you here.) what i'm trying to learn is the full, accurate piano part in the original key, from the Shaking The Tree version. i don't think i communicated my questions very well though, or at all, so i'll try again.

i have experience in percussion, but also some guitar and mandolin, learning with tabs and by ear - i'm the one that thinks strings sound soapy. but i can JUST BARELY read music at all. i am teaching myself piano, and how to read music. right now my ears are ahead of my fingers and feet, which are all MILES ahead of what i can actually read. there's a lot of "music language" that i've been exposed to but don't really understand yet. i want to learn this stuff so i can play and communicate with others better, and to be able to write down things i make up.

my strategy is: A) have fun learning songs that i like as accurately as i can, by ear. B) learn to read using beginner music books and get frustrated because i can only read things like hot cross buns so far. (maybe a tad more advanced than that.) it was fairly equal a month ago but now i spend 95% of the time i play on A and 5% on B. so, i haven't progressed on reading much. that's problem 1.

problem 2 is: i think i have a pretty good ear. BUT i sometimes hit a limit: when it gets to be 5 or 6 or more keys pressed at the same time, it all starts to sound like One Big Thing and i have trouble distinguishing the notes, especially low ones. (keep in mind that i can't NAME the notes/chords from hearing them, i can just copy what i hear after hunting around a bit.) i know some musicians are able to identify notes in big chords really easily and accurately, and it seems almost like they were just born with that ability, which is kind of scary,

q.q: I was watching the Joy of Painting the other day. I don't know how familiar you are with Bob Ross' videos...

q.a: well the important thing to remember here is he is doing a regular scheduled TV show with firm time limits. this is one of the gorgeous things about a regular content schedule, with time limits. things get done. and after doing so many shows of exactly the same length, you become very good at knowing exactly what is gonna work in that time frame. you know exactly how much time you have to do the sky. you know exactly when you have to decide on your mountains. you know exactly when to get to the tree highlights. and exactly when you'll have a moment to tell a brief story about some crazy shit you've seen in alaska
q.q: but his approach to creating art is just unbelievable. And insanely inspiring. In almost every painting he'll say something like "now it's time to make a big decision" then without seemingly even thinking about it he'll just paint a giant fucking tree or mountain or something right in the middle of the foreground, that takes up a huge chunk of the painting, even covering up things he's already painted in the background... and it winds up working beautifully. I know so many artists, writers, musicians etc who are so meticulous and who spend more time thinking about what they're gonna do, then they do actually doing the thing. Like when I'm writing a song... I scrutinize every single phrase.. is that the best rhythm? Should I use a different chord to harmonize this note? Should this be louder or softer, should I use this effect, etc. But if I w ere Bob Ross, I would just throw a big old wrench into the song on a whim, and make it work. ('This is your world, and in your world, notes can live wherever you want them to. Let's put this note here. That's nice. Let's put this chord here'). Do you think that you're able to approach your content in the 'Bob Ross way'?

q.a: i don't really have any fast techniques. usually it just involves asking a lot of questions and using process of elimination to eventually narrow it down. you have to be patient, it can take a while. but in the past few years i've succeeded at it enough times that i am confident that the answer is always there if you wait for it. some examples of questions you might want to be asking, let's say for example you have your chorus and now you're trying to figure out what the verse figure is that comes before it, examples of questions would be-- does it want the same chord for or different chord form? in many songs it is a no brainer that the verse and chorus use the same form, and that's fine. some songs it is supposed to be different. so first we want to narrow it down and see which one feels right for this song. often you get a clear answer yes or no. just a lot of narrowing it down. another thing which SOMETIMES works is see what goes well AFTER the chorus, like see what would be good for a second verse. but you're still going to be left with the puzzle of what will do best as the first verse, especially if the first verse starts the song. i have no good tricks for this, just spend time narrowing it down and trying things and seeing if they work. and i've gotten this now enough times that i always know there is a solution, so i know to be patient with it and keep asking questions

q.a: step 1 is, find the beat. so as the music is going, see where you would tap your foot or nod your head, or wave your conducting wand. in most songs, this is pretty easy to find. of course you could always make crazy songs where you can't find it, but in Most songs you can find it. however, in most songs you can also do it twice as slow (or half as fast) if you want. in some songs, it is at just a certain tempo that you're almost not sure whether to tap the beat at one speed or twice as fast. this is ok, any piece of music can be written in multiple ways, you could set the tempo twice as fast and write all the notes as half the values and it would mean the same thing. but in most songs, it is reasonably clear where the foot-tap is. and i will go a step further to say that most music usually has these beats grouped together in groups of 2, 4, 8, etc. the way most music is written on paper is in groups of 4 beats, with bar lines dividing the bars (or 'measures'). most music uses 4 beats per bar. that being said it is really up to you to decide where the begining of the bars should be. but i think in most music there is a clear answer. to learn how to detect other time signatures besides 4/4, just start finding examples of them and then you will get better at hearing them. but when songs use 3-based time signatures, it can often be represented in multiple ways, many of which actually still heavily involve 4s. 2s, 3s, and 4s, are used all the time in music. it is very rare that music consistently uses a 5 or 7 pattern all the way through. usually when time signatures like 5 or 7 happen, it tends to be only once, and then goes back to 4. it is quite common for songs to need to add an extra beat or half a beat here and there, particularly at the end of the chorus or at the end of a section. this is accomplished by having 1 bar that is a different time signature. it is much more rare to have a song that entirely is based on a 5 pattern or a 7 pattern or another higher odd number. i'm not sure if that answers your question actually, but i think my most important point is that most music is in groups of 2, 4, and 8. and the way that is most commonly written on paper is with 4 beats per bar, and the time signature is called "4/4" (actually the first number is written above the second number but that's not easy to type here) the top or first number represents how many beats per bar. the bottom (or second) number is supposed to tell you what kind of a note gets the beat. so 4/4 should technically mean there are 4 beats in a bar and a 'quarter' note gets 1 beat. i realize there are holes in this system and many time signatures really can't be analyzed quite this way but that is the way the idea is supposed to work

q.a: there are 3 worlds you may find yourself in when playing piano, with regard to which hand does what. world 1 is where your left hand plays the bass notes (one note at a time) your right hand plays the chords, and you are singing the melody (or someone else is singing/playing the melody. World 2 is where you already have a bass player playing the bass notes, and you have to take care of the chords and the melody. world 3 is where you are in a band where someone else is playing the bass, and someone else is playing the melody, and you are only playing the chords. so in other words, we have 3 different elements- bass, chords, and melody. and depending on the situation you are playing in, you may be taking care of a different number of those things. each situation requires totally different things

q.q: Hey, I asked a question a little while ago about vocal harmonies. Another thing I'm curious about, that I forgot to mention in my other question, is doubling notes in different instruments.

q.a: you have to specify which octave. chords behave differently texturally depending on which octave, especially when we're talking about arranging which instruments play what
q.q: For simplicity sake, say you have a good old ii-V-I in C. If the bass player is playing the roots, D to G to C, then on piano I won't want to play the chords starting on those same roots. So I'd maybe play FACE, FABE, then EABD.

q.a: playing what melody, is there a melody or are they playing their own melody
q.q: Okay. So, then say I want to add maybe a 4 part vocal harmony over that, or a 4 part horn arrangement.

q.a: usually i think you'll find when arranging for a band, you're usuallly going to want to not go too far beyond what a single piano player could play with 2 hands. (or even one.) Doubling notes is fine and great. i think if you were to take all the notes that anyone is playing at any given time, octave specific, and diagram them on the piano, i think it should really usually only be between like 4 and 9 notes. but you'll have to try and see. but if you have multiple chordal instruments, horns, voices, whatever, i think it would be a bad strategy to try to put everyone on different notes on purpose. on that Dmin7, everyone should gravitate toward that F note, and/or the A and C notes, right around the middle range, and when theres more players just be gentle and let those notes just sing and glow as each instrument approaches those voicings in whatever way their instrument works best-- so ideally you should get a nicely layered sound that just sounds like a 2-4 note chord that sounds like a very healthy blend, where all the most important notes are being played by approximately 2 and a half people. but you'll just have to try and see
q.q: Would I want that arrangement to have the same extensions that I'm doing on piano (Dm9, G9/13, Cmaj6/9)? Is it a good strategy to take the same notes the piano is playing, but just voice them in a different order/inversion? Do I want to double all those same notes? I know there's not set "rules" or anything. And you can write horn arrangements/vocal arrangements in any way that sounds good to you. But I'm new to this kind of thing, and just interested in any tips or "strategies" you may have.

q.a: just tried to choose whatever lines were best for the song at each point. in some cases this means emotional. in some cases this means unexpected. any line could be in some way connected to the title, or not. emotions, hopes/dreams, aspirations, friendship, loneliness, they all factor in. most of the lines are questions and maybes, so there are oceans of room for the feelings to be projected any which way. movie star is a somewhat antequated phrase so it was fun to play around with. tried to keep it abstract but make the feelings still feel real, which always feels like a magic trick if you can pull it off, so that's a target i frequently try to hit in songwriting

q.a: it's pretty simple. i think it's important to start simple. only put a harmony on like 1 thing. like maybe that special line in the 2nd verse. only add 1 harmony note. i think it's ususlly pretty clear what to add. but the only way to know is just try it. one important thing to remember is keep the mix lower than the lead. put it on loop and select your harmony tracks and slide them down until it sounds right. harmonies mostly will work best in the 'chord range' which is usually like middle C and above. if your lead vocal is male and in the mid-low range (like below middle C) just remember that your harmonies will usually want to be higher. then just try stuff and see what works

q.a: the way i do it is i just talk to the thing for hundreds and thousands of hours over the course of many years, being excited about the fact that i can one day cut it together tightly with captions and graphics to actually make it interesting, but keep kicking that project down the road year after year while still recording more and more audio on a regular basis. then right after i get a big youtube hit i decide i can let that ride for a moment and get the journal edits project started once and for all. so i go through about 7000 clips and edit together the last 5 years worth of material, which takes 3 months, meanwhile my general audience thinks i'm 'dead' and have 'quit', then finally once i release the journals on a brand new page containing the journals all the way up until the date i started the editing, people look at this brand new content and asked why i 'stopped' after the latest journal date, which is not the date that i stopped at all, but rather the date that i started the entire editing process. then a year and a half later when i finally try to do another round of editing/releasing, again i find that it's taking up all of my time and i can't get to regular videos/music. and people still ask why i 'stopped' doung journals even while i am editing and releasing them, and they also ask when the next main project is which i still haven't gotten to because i've been doing journal edits. i'm not sure if that answers your question

q.q: okay so i've got a case of what i've heard called "the everything thing." i'm obsessive and perfectionistic by nature. i can't remember a time when i wasn't aware of my own mortality and felt like there was a ticking timer on my life, and i had to just DO AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE. i go the extra 23094823 miles when i care about something. and there are plenty of things that i DON'T give two damns about, but there are SOOO MANY THINGS THAT I DO CARE ABOUT. and i see people who have put a shit ton of work into one of those things. like a successful musician. or a top tier pastry chef. or a talented painter. or a film editor, or blah blah blah a hundred other things I wanna be. and i'm like. shit. because i've hit that place where i'm so ready to put in the work, and i AM. like, between paying the bills and school i AM putting in the //work.// but it's so spread between all the Things that my progress in each of them is excruciatingly slow. i could pour myself into music and leave film and art and cooking and building things and agriculture and physics and everything else by the wayside, and i would probably progress faster and get to Play With the Big Kids sooner. but.... then i wouldn't have those other things in my life. or i could pursue all of them equally and maybe never break free from only being mediocre-to-good-ish at any of them. i don't wanna be presumptuous but i feel like you gotta know what i'm talking about. how do/did you deal with those feelings??? was/is the answer (in your experience) more focus, or just faith that you actually do have enough time in your lifetime to pour into everything you care about with an end result that you can be proud of? the only thing i know is that i can't let indecision hinder me any longer.

q.a: i agree fully
q.q: I think when you're improvising, you shouldn't be thinking about scales and stuff, you should be thinking about the melody and harmony of the song.

q.a: there are a couple of strategies. when you start to know a lot of songs, you start to recognize where a song is going and what it's doing, especially if it's a relatively 'normal' type of song. Look ahead, like to the whole line, and you should be able to get an idea of what's happening, at least if it's anything reasonably 'normal' going on. it should jump out at you. the more songs you know and the more experience you have, the easier this will be. But some songs might be more unexpected, experimental, and you might not be as sure where they're going. So if things start to feel uncertain, that's where you have to just start to zoom in slightly closer, and only look at 2 bars. worst case scenario, you JUST look at the one chord, and then just use the 'available notes' in a technical way. But usually you should be able to zoom out to AT LEAST 2 chords, or hopefully more. and the farther you zoom out, the better an idea you should get of what's going on. but let's say it's worst case and you really aren't sure where things are going and you are just looking at 1 chord, i still think 'scales' are not quite the right way to look at it. Just be aware of what the good notes usually are, and sort of rank them. The real good notes will vary depending on the context of the song obviously, and if you really know the song this will change everything, but as you said you are looking for tricks to use when you really don't know the context and all you have is a chord symbol staring you in the face. just sort of rank the notes. and there are all kinds of clues that will change things. so let's say the chord you're looking at is Fmaj7. well even still you can look at context. is the song in C, or in F? that will usually change the context. but on Fmaj7 your strongest notes are going to be E, A, and C. next probably G. If the chord is Cmin7, your strong notes are going to be Eb, then G, then Bb. again, context will always change this, but these are sort of the technical best options for when you really don't understand the context, for whatever reason (like if it's just a strange song doing a disorienting thing). for dominant 7th chords, there are a million zillion contexts for those chords, so you're really gonna have to know the song to figure out what's going on there, but your guaranteed available notes for example on G7 would be B and F. beyond that, anything else is kind of risking it, because 7th chords can be in all kinds of crazy contexts. sometimes specifics will be added. so let's say if it says G9 (which means G7 with a 9 on it) then you've got B, F, and A for sure. almost even favor A, because if the writer wrote G9, that must mean the A note is important. so just go for that note. if it's G7b9 then you'll be fine with B, F, and Ab. Zooming out a little bit more to a 3 chord sequence, things get clearer. since you mentioned the real book, I'll mention certain things that would occur there. if you're in Cmaj and you see D-7, G7, Cma7, you should really be looking at that whole figure altogether. basically what that figure means is "we're coming in for a normal landing on Cmaj." so just, i dunno, just get used to stuff you can play over that. don't think about the chords individually, think about coming for a landing on Cmaj at the designated time. your F note is going to be in the running for the entire time BEFORE the landing, and when the landing hits you will want to be on E, G, perhaps B, maybe D. prior to the landing you will want to be using notes like D, F, also G, A, etc.. Looking at the case of a minor key version of the same thing, the familiar pattern (again speaking in terms of the real book) would be something like Dmin7b5, G7b9, Cmin. again, this means "coming in for a landing on Cmin"... resolving to C minor is a little bit more interesting, and a bit more crazy things are usually possible. Ab note will feature prominently BEFORE the landing, and you will want to land on G, Eb, perhaps D if it's a Cmin9 specifically, etc. before the resolution, B, D, F, also Eb, Bb should all be fine. When a G7 resolves to Cmin in the key of Cmin, that is an especially strong case of "not all notes behave equally" -- this is really always true, and again that's why i don't like to use scales because scales implies that all notes are equal. and that's really not true. it's like characters in a movie. sure all the characters are there, but they all have different personalities, have different roles to play, and are featured with different levels of prominence. Again, in general when improvising, always zoom out as much as possible and try to gather a sense of where the landing points are, identify when it's getting to where it's going. usually you can tell pretty clearly by zooming out, and it gets easier the more experience you have. If you have a clear idea of where the thing is going by the end of the line, or by the beginning of the next line, you can really lean back and go wherever you want to go in the meantime, because you know very clearly when it has to get to where it has to go, and it will feel fine. it's like going down a staircase. you can do as many backflips as you want and you don't even have to touch any of the stairs as long as you land at the bottom of the stairs at the right time

q.q: I dont understand how people identify time signatures in almost all music (pop, rock, jazz, etc, etc). I play classical music,

q.a: step 1 is, find the beat. so as the music is going, see where you would tap your foot or nod your head, or wave your conducting wand. in most songs, this is pretty easy to find. of course you could always make crazy songs where you can't find it, but in Most songs you can find it. however, in most songs you can also do it twice as slow (or half as fast) if you want. in some songs, it is at just a certain tempo that you're almost not sure whether to tap the beat at one speed or twice as fast. this is ok, any piece of music can be written in multiple ways, you could set the tempo twice as fast and write all the notes as half the values and it would mean the same thing. but in most songs, it is reasonably clear where the foot-tap is. and i will go a step further to say that most music usually has these beats grouped together in groups of 2, 4, 8, etc. the way most music is written on paper is in groups of 4 beats, with bar lines dividing the bars (or 'measures'). most music uses 4 beats per bar. that being said it is really up to you to decide where the begining of the bars should be. but i think in most music there is a clear answer. to learn how to detect other time signatures besides 4/4, just start finding examples of them and then you will get better at hearing them. but when songs use 3-based time signatures, it can often be represented in multiple ways, many of which actually still heavily involve 4s. 2s, 3s, and 4s, are used all the time in music. it is very rare that music consistently uses a 5 or 7 pattern all the way through. usually when time signatures like 5 or 7 happen, it tends to be only once, and then goes back to 4. it is quite common for songs to need to add an extra beat or half a beat here and there, particularly at the end of the chorus or at the end of a section. this is accomplished by having 1 bar that is a different time signature. it is much more rare to have a song that entirely is based on a 5 pattern or a 7 pattern or another higher odd number. i'm not sure if that answers your question actually, but i think my most important point is that most music is in groups of 2, 4, and 8. and the way that is most commonly written on paper is with 4 beats per bar, and the time signature is called "4/4" (actually the first number is written above the second number but that's not easy to type here) the top or first number represents how many beats per bar. the bottom (or second) number is supposed to tell you what kind of a note gets the beat. so 4/4 should technically mean there are 4 beats in a bar and a 'quarter' note gets 1 beat. i realize there are holes in this system and many time signatures really can't be analyzed quite this way but that is the way the idea is supposed to work

q.a: there are 2 ways to be introduced to black keys. let's start by staying in the key of C. play the first 5 notes, up and down, c,d,e,f,g,f,e,d,c. this is part of the "key of C", specifically the key of C major.  actually, it's all 7 notes all the way up. c,d,e,f,g,a,b,c. but let's just look at the first 5-- c,d,e,f,g. try JUST c, e, and g, all together at the same time. that's a chord. the name of that chord is C major. it is like your home chord in the key of C. ok great. now, plot twist, let's try a black note. instead of E, play the black note to the left of it instead (that note is called "E flat" which is written as E&flat or Eb if you don't have the flat symbol handy... whenever i type Eb it means "E flat") ..... so any time you would have played E, play Eb instead. so going up the first 5 notes of the C major scale but switching in Eb instead, you get C, D, Eb, F, G. and back down, G, F, Eb, D, C.  you'll notice it has a darker sound, like "sad" basically. this is called C minor. try the chord, C, Eb, G. that is a "C minor" chord. the C minor scale going all the way up is usually C, D, Eb, F, G, Ab, Bb, C. but the top part of the scale has a few different options that come into play that we'll worry about once we start seeing them actually in songs. mess around with the notes in C minor a little bit, especially the first 5 notes. for a challenge, see if you can figure out "the ants go marching 1 by 1", which is a kids song in a minor key. hint: you will need to include notes all the way down to the G below your root C. hint: the word "march" will be on C, and the word "one" will be on Eb. let me know if you can figure this out
q.q: bill ive been pounding out kids songs like you wouldn't believe. it's very easy. why don't kids songs get to have the black keys? why are they special?

q.a: you just have to start by experimenting. anything is possible, and the possibilities might be overwhelming at first. you can literally do anything. just start trying things and go from there
q.q: I'm not good at writing songs, but I'm good at playing them, how do you write songs?

q.a: for the peter gabriel song, are you doing the vocal melody? for this one you will need to expand the range to include down to the G below your low C. i don't know if that helps. Also, I should mention, when you are learning these melodies, they will not necessarily be in the same key as the recording -- meaning, they will sound like the song if you play it by itself. but if you compare it with the recording, the whole thing may be higher or lower. also, not every song is possible to play all in 1 key. some times it borrows notes from other keys (for example, in C that means using the black notes). are you familiar with the the traditional alphabet song (also known as twinkle twinkle little star), or row, row, row your boat, or happy birthday? Try those. hint: happy birthday will actually require you to expand the range down to G, when playing it in the key of C. happy birthday would start on the low G note. the other 2 songs should start on C and only use the notes from C to C. let me know if this helps. all this is called "playing in the key of C", where the C note will feel like your home base. for example, if we were to play these songs in the key of D, all the notes would be up a little higher, and as an added twist you have to swap in a couple of black notes to get it to sound right. but you will learn that later

q.a: attack is how quickly the note starts. so if 'attack' is set all the way short, the note starts immediately when you press the note. if 'attack' is set to a longer setting, the note will gradually fade in when you press the note. Decay is what happens to the note when you keep holding it down. very short decay means the note will drop off to silence immediately, even if you are holding it down. longer decay means it will fade out very very slowly as you hold it down, or maybe even never fade. release is what happens to the note after you let go. short release means the note disappears instantly when you let go. long release means it lingers after you let go, and fades slowly, or even if you set the release to maximum, it will probably stay forever. Sustain is an additional bonus option. instead of "decay" decaying to 0 volume, you can set 'sustain' at a certain level and that will be the volume level that it decays to while you are still holding the note down. then when you let go, the 'release' happens from there. so for example, if you set all 4 sliders (attack, decay, sustain, release) to "medium", and you press your note and hold it, the note will fade in at a medium pace, then drop down at a medium pace to a medium level. then when you let go it will drop to silence at a medium pace. i hope that makes sense

q.a: you really need to get this. it might seem scary at first but it doesn't take long. look at it this way, take a small range -- like the range right around middle C, (because that's actually the range the probably most chords will want to be) -- and make every chord fit right in there. because this is actually what your inversion skills are going to be used for. playing multiple chords in 1 range without having to jump the range just because you only know a certain inversion. so just pick one small range and make all the chords fit in there. then slide the range up by a 5th or so, and then do it again, find all your chords in that range. you need to be able to do this and i think you can actually learn it very quickly

This happens because some lights flicker with the AC power at 50 or 60 Hz, and some of the segments are out of phase with the others. So if you vibrate your head up and down at about the same frequency, you see some lights appear to be higher or lower than others, depending whether your head is at the top or bottom of its vibration when that light flickers.

I find it works best with LED Christmas lights, but oven displays are pretty good too.

q.a: i think the challenges you mentioned are very possible to overcome. use a digital voice memo recorder. the one i use can hold 17 hours, and the battery life lasts for probably 10 hours but maybe more. i bought it 8 years ago, so i'm sure they're better now. but i was going to suggest you use 2. with a little practice and planning you could alternate between them. it is likely that you would only need to switch once. the next challenge is editing, but i think you can use multiplication to your advantage. and you will probably use different programs, depending on what does what better... or maybe you can do it in one. i'm pretty sure there are programs that will open a 24 hour file. really you just need to use that program to break it into 24 pieces. make sure volume is at 0 (even, not plus or minus anything), and there is no master compression or anything (garage band for example has some automatic compression i think but that will mess you up for this project). then once you have it down to 1 hour pieces, i would suggest opening them up in a program like logic or protools, and just put them all in on 24 tracks. that should be reasonable. again, no compression, and from here on, make sure that all tracks are set to about -15db, because the noise is going to stack up. export this 1 hour of 24 tracks stacked together. then open a new file and import this, and cut it into let's say 30. 30 tracks of 2 minutes each. make sure you set your time settings to be by time, and grid snap to minutes, OR if it is on a musical bars/measures setting, just set your tempo to 120 bpm (which it likely already is by default) and 2 minutes should be exactly 60 bars. so cut every 2 minutes, that's the beginning of bar 61, 121, 181, 241, and so on. stack them all down vertically, so you have 30 tracks of 2 minute regions. export this. again, NO master compression, and i think from here on you can keep your volume at 0 -- the trick is to make sure that it was low enough on the one where you lowered it. maybe even -20 would have been good, to be safe. so now you should have 1 file that's 2 minutes long that has everything. repeat the process, you are almost done, split this into 8 if you want 15 second final length, split it into 12 if you want 10 second final length, or split it into 24 if you want 5 second final length. at 120 bpm, 5 seconds is 2 and a half bars. 10 seconds is 5 bars, 15 seconds is 7 and a half bars. (that's if you are in a musical program measuring by bar. otherwise just set it to time grid). split it up, stack it up, no compression, keep the volume at zero, and then you should be done. I think this process is actually within reach. the exporting could take a while in the first round. but i think if you try different programs and perhaps toy with the values in this system, i think you can get there. Now, here is the bigger challenge, which i don't really have a solution for -- you're going to have an insane amount of walking noise, pocket noise, or even if you keep the thing out of your pocket the whole time, there is going to be loud unwanted noise any time you touch the device, or if you set it down, basically unless you are holding it the right way in your hand for the entire time. that is probably going to be the bigger challenge. because i think over 24 hours, all that noise will add up and that will be all you hear. you won't be able to hear any of the ambient noise you're looking for, because the direct mic contact noise will be about 5 times louder and i think it will fill the whole time when stacked 144,000 times. now it might be possible to use a noise gate that actually silences anything above a certain db. i'm not sure if these exist, i only know of noise gates that silence anything BELOW a certain level, or just flatten anything above a certain level, which is not what you want because you will still hear all the mic contact noises. but if you can get a noise gate that can silence anything above a certain db, i think that could be just the ticket, with some experimentation. i would recommend putting that on at the 1 hour level, applying it to all 24 1-hour tracks. i hope that helps

q.a: over and over and over again, people talk about learning music like it's something that someone else has to give to you, or like it's something that someone else can just make you do. that's just not how it worked for me. sure, there is a lot of language for music, like knowing the note names, even knowing what the common industry names are for chords. but that information is all out there readily available ESPECIALLY now with the internet. the only way any of that information is going to make sense is if you actually try it out. and when you are ready to learn what things are called, i think you will find that the information will be readily available. i will also readily provide that information as well. like for example, if anyone asks me what any note is called, or if anyone says "is there a special name for when you play C, Eb, and G at the same time", i will readily and gladly say "that's a C minor chord." but if someone asks 'how to use theory to get music to sound good', i will explain again and again and again that the way to do this, and the way to learn how to do it, is by using your own experience, your own mind, your own hands, and your own ears, otherwise you're just not going to get the good stuff. i will keep trying to explain this to people until the apocolypse, maybe even after that

Isn't it a little disingenious to just say to people to mess around with music when there's so much more to music than that? q.a: the chorus has 9 beats in the cycle. you can break it up however you choose, but i chose to hear it as alternating 4/4 + 5/4. the verses are initially based on that pattern but break it also.
q.q: in i wanna be a movie star is the chorus like 16/16 or whatever and then the verse 9/8 or am i just really bad at figuring out time signatures?

q.a: those are all mathematically the same (like the bars will look the same on paper) but usually the second number says what kind of note gets the beat. so like, in 4/4, the quarter note is where the beat is. in 2/2 (also nicknamed "cut time") the bars look exactly the same, but the half note gets the beat (you tap your foot on the half note intead of the quarter note.) the main difference would really be the tempo -- cut time (2/2) is designed for the bars to basically go twice as fast. and when you see a tempo marking on the top of the page, it will say "half note = xxx b.p.m" instead of "quarter note = xxx b.p.m". so in cut time (2/2) the bars will usually go by twice as fast. what the point of this is exactly, i'm not sure. i think cut time was used much more 100 years ago. perhaps people were too lazy to write 16th notes and preferred to use 8th notes for the fast stuff instead. i'm not sure. 8/8 and 16/16 are really never used. time signatures ending in 8 also don't necessarily follow this rule of what note gets the beat, for example sometimes 7/8 is used when in reality the quarter note should get the beat, and the actual time signature would be "3 and a half/4" but no one says that for insanity reasons. also 6/8 is very very commonly counted as the dotted quarter note getting the beat, in which case the actual time signature would technically be "2/2.66666" which again would be completely insane to see written on the page
q.q: speaking of, what is the difference between 4/4 8/8 16/16 2/2 or anything else like that

q.q: I'm not quite sure how to put this... I know you say that the best chord is the one that supports the melody and that the melody and chords are inherently connected to each other... but I guess I'm wondering if you got any tips on working out specific chord voicings? I can come up with chords that I think are a good fit with the melody.. but too often I find myself just doubling the chord in my left and right hand (on piano btw) which probably isn't the best thing to do.

q.a: in a certain range (bass/low) only use single notes. right in the middle near middle C, that is usually where the heart of your chord lives. Believe it or not, the melody actually should go there too, usually on a different instrument. in the higher range way above that will be sprinkles and twinkles. it's almost always a bad idea to play exactly the same chord configuration in different octaves. it's kind of like writing on a paper that's a gradient from top to bottom. if you write with the same color pen from top to bottom, on a gradually shaded page, the pen is going to have a different visual effect depending on what part of the page its on
q.q: I know it depends on the particular arrangement of the song, but what are some good ways to get around this?

q.a: not good to think in 'chords' with both hands. think about building chords using the whole keyboard, and throw the 'stacked thirds' theory of chords out the window, and just start from scratch. find the notes you need, on the whole keyboard, and use only the notes you need. it might only be one note, it might be 2. and use whatever hands you need, in order to play the notes you need, wherever they may be. Another way of looking at it -- if you are by yourself, play chords with your right hand and play bass (1 note!) with your left. Or, if you are playing the melody and chords, and someone else is the bass player, then i guess play chords in the middle range with your LEFT hand, and do the melody with your right hand. and if your band already has a bass player and someone else playing the melody, then tie one hand behind your back.
q.q: Sometimes I'll play different inversions. Like for example to do like a cm9 chord I might play a cm7 (C,Eb,G,Bb) with the left hand and a Ebmaj7 (Eb,G,Bb,D) with my right.... but I don't know.

q.a: the bass should only be 1 note at a time. the way the notes work is, the lower you go, the less notes you can play. this is a very clearly defined thing, there is something called "lower interval limits" and i think if you look it up you will find very clearly when to stop using which intervals as you go lower. actually, don't look it up, just experiment for yourself. 1 note is the lowest -- for example, the lower interval limit is, let's say, the B at the very bottom of a grand piano. that's the lowest you can really go and have the note still sound like a note (i'm sure people will argue that the limit is actually lower, but i don't really care, beyond that low B it really turns to mud). actually screw it let's say C because it's easier for this example. so let's say low C on the 88key piano is the lowest limit for single note (this also happens to be right at the bottom of the range of the 5 string bass guitar) ok so that's the lower limit for 1 note. next thing to look at is a perfect fifth. the lower interval limit for a perfect 5th is exactly 1 octave above that -- which in this case means C and G, in the second octave of a grand piano -- so the second lowest C and the second lowest G. This would be about as low as you can put perfect 5ths and still have them sound coherent (again, people will argue that you can go lower, but for the sake of this example i'm keeping it at C). Next look at 4ths -- this piggybacks on the 5th -- the same G, and the next C. that is the lowest your 4ths are going to work. I should mention, in heavy rock bands with distorted guitars, all those heavy metal riffs are usually written with "power chords" which is root-5th-root, hugging the lower limit, and the bass is an octave down, also hugging the lower limit for single note. standard tuning puts both instruments at E, and many bands downtune and B is just about as low as they usually go, before it starts becoming unintelligible. this is another simple way to observe the lower-limit phenomenon in common practice among distorted guitar metal bands, etc. So piggybacking on what we have so far (did i mention we are just climbing up the harmonic series) the next note on top of that C would be E. so for major thirds, that would be the lower limit for 3rds. counting Cs up from the bottom of the grand piano, that would be the 3rd C and the E above it. that should be about as low as major 3rds will work. continuing on, the next note in the harmonic series is G, so the minor third right there (E-G) in that octave should be the lowest that minor thirds will be happy. again, the lower limits are actually perhaps a few notes lower than all the ones i'm mentioning, i'm just putting it a little higher and keeping it in C for the sake of the explanation. that is basically how it works. tigher clusters gradually work better as you go up, bass only works with single notes, a little higher and 5ths work but not 3rds, and then the 3rds become clear a little higher, etc etc. i hope this makes sense. imagine your pen gets thicker as the notes get lower. so you have to write bigger and make the linest further apart. where as up higher, it's like writing with a smaller pen, you can do much more complicated smaller designs and still see it. i just realized i have probably explained this entire thing on this questions page at least a couple of times before
q.q: Sometimes that big full sounds good with solo piano, but it can be too much with a full band. As a general guideline, is it better to use less notes in the bass and put the bulk of the h armony h igher up?

q.a: sure, but there are new techniques. or you can use old techniques too if you want. maybe even use future techniques
q.q: I was reading about how musicians use to get different effects and sounds from their instruments 'back in the day.' Some pretty cool stuff. In You Really Got Me, Ray Davies apparently used a razor blade to splice the speaker cone in his amp and poked pins into the cone. In Street Fighting Man, Keith Richards got an electric-guitar sound from an acoustic by using a tape cassette to record and overdub the parts and by playing right up to the mic. Link Wray used to poke holes in his speaker cone with pencils to get that fuzzy tone. You had all sorts of experimentation with reel to reel tape recorders to get echos and other weird effects. Lots of old blues guitarists would turn the gain and volume all the way up on lo-fi amps to the point of nearly blowing out the speakers to get their sounds. Sam Phillips (who produced a lot of those 50's rockabilly/rock 'n' roll records with Sun Records) would re-feed the playback from the recorder to the head, adjusti ng the s pace between the heads, tape speed and other stuff to make crazy echo and delay effects.... Today with all sorts of effects pedals, built in effects on amplifiers, digital recording sofwares where you can alter the sounds in so many different ways, do you think that these "proto-effects" or these old recording techniques are obsolete?

q.a: those techniques you mentioned never really made sense for me because i grew up in the digital age. but there are plenty of interesting rebellious "wrong" practices you can do in the digital age, or in any age. for example in the video "Are you the Real You" i decided to not actually crop out the screen fully on some of those text items, so some of the computer menus and window edges can actually be seen in the video. it was originally a mistake, but it adds character so i left it in. another crazy technique someone showed me many years ago was to open a picture in a text program (it looks like nonsense text) and start changing the letters. the picture glitches out in weird ways. i've never actually used that but that's another example of ways you can have fun in the post digital age
q.q: When you're recording do you ever experiment with any of this type of stuff to create effects or different sounds, or do you it all on the computer, effects pedals, etc.?
